awd_titl_txt: SCH: EAGER: New Approach: Early Diagnosis of Alzheimer's Disease Based on Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) via High-Dimensional Image Feature Identification
awd_abstract_narration:
Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a form of progressive neurodegenerative dementia and one of the most common diseases in the aging population. Early diagnosis of AD is strongly recommended for several reasons. First, it can helps to significantly reduce the social and economic impacts caused by AD and allow people to better manage and plan ahead. Second, it may provide more information for  researchers seeking new scientific approaches for early treatment and intervention. However, in current clinical practice early diagnosis is often a challenge. While neuroimaging is routinely collected in hospitals, it is very hard for radiologists to manually read the high-dimensional image data for analysis and interpretation. This project proposes untested but potentially transformative research approaches to identify high-dimensional image features for AD early diagnosis based on Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). This project will advance the research in machine learning, optimization, statistics, image science and bioinformatics, and potentially be used to address other high-dimensional images besides brain images. The project also has broader impacts through cross-disciplinary research, training and education.
 
This project has the following two aims: 1) Develop sparse coding based algorithms to identify features of structural MRI images for classifying AD patients and other diagnostic groups. This will allow the key structural features of images that separate AD patients, individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or healthy individuals to be identified. 2) Develop optimization and machine learning algorithms based on tensor Tucker core decomposition for high-dimensional image-marker detection from longitudinal functional MRI images. This approach should reduce the high computational complexity of marker detection from the longitudinal MRI images of AD patients. It is anticipated that the developed algorithms will enhance high-dimensional neuroimaging marker detection and diagnostic classification. This research project, if successful, will greatly impact the current practice of AD diagnosis by providing clinical doctors with the information from a larger population and also significantly easing the burden of radiologists.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This NSF fund supports research in early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease (AD) based on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).  AD is a form of progressive neurodegenerative dementia and one of the most common diseases in the aging population. In current clinical practice early diagnosis is often a challenge. While neuroimaging is routinely collected in hospitals, it is very hard for radiologists to manually read the high-dimensional image data for analysis and interpretation. This project proposes transformative research approaches to identify high-dimensional image features for AD early diagnosis based on Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). This project helps advance the research in machine learning, optimization, statistics, image science and bioinformatics, and potentially be used to address other high-dimensional images besides brain images. The project also has broader impacts through cross-disciplinary research, training and education. 

The developed algorithms, with the mathematical optimization models and machine learning feature analysis, address the challenges of high-dimensional neuroimaging marker detection and diagnostic classification. The algorithms can identify features of structural MRI images for classifying AD patients and other diagnostic groups, including individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or healthy individuals. This research project potentially impacts the current practice of AD diagnosis by providing clinical doctors with the information from a larger population and help easing the burden of radiologists. 

This research project has provided great training experience for undergraduate and graduate students. The fund supported REU undergraduate research training; one of the students presented in Washington DC at the NSF meeting and was later admitted to graduate program. One PhD student was trained with research of this project and already graduated and started a tenure track faculty position in Arkansas. Three students are currently in good progress with their graduate studies at Arkansas State University.   

Besides the support for research and education efforts, this grant also helps support the following activities and efforts: (i) The National AI-Campus. PI founded the National Artificial Intelligence (AI) Campus, which is being expanded from the Arkansas AI-Campus effort. (ii) The Center for No-Boundary Thinking (CNBT). The Center was established with the approval of Arkansas Higher Education Coordinating Board and CNBT started with four divisions. CNBT is to develop human infrastructure (HI) at the frontier of bioinformatics, advanced data science and artificial intelligence, as part of its broader mission to address research challenges without the boundary of disciplines. (iii) NBT workshops. Based on the concept of No-Boundary Thinking (NBT), two NBT workshops were hosted in 2021, and two NBT workshops were hosted in 2022. 


Last Modified: 11/24/2022
Modified by: Xiuzhen Huang
